text.tspan: The Indian education system is largely governed by three national boards: the Central
Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), the Council for the Indian School Certificate
Examination (CISCE), and the National Institute of Open Schooling (NIOS). Apart from these,
there also exist State Boards, which have syllabi based on the locally-relevant curriculum and are
operated individually by the State Governments. All students prepare for board examinations in
10th and 12th-grade.
The 10th-grade ends with the first board exam, a crucial factor in determining the stream
of education students pursue in successive grades. Streams are categorized mainly into science,
humanities, and commerce. In a country where 37.3% of the graduates who have a technical
education degree remain unemployed (Mehrotra & Parida, 2019), students are pressured by
family members to take science as their stream because it leads to more extensive job
opportunities (Deb et al., 2015). For most boards, including CBSE and CISCE, students cannot
change their stream after registration for the 12th-grade board examination, which takes place
during the middle of the 11th-grade academic session. Thus, students need to decide on their
subjects within a limited time and without any subsequent flexibility.
The 12th-grade board examination plays an elemental role for admittance into a preferred
university or college. Furthermore, science students experience added pressure to score high
marks in the university entrance exams required for pursuing specialized courses such as those
for engineering and medical degrees. University entrance exam cut-offs (minimum marks for
qualification) in India's most renowned colleges are becoming astoundingly competitive,
reaching anywhere between 89%-99% in 2019 (Iftikhar & Sarfaraz, 2019).
